parameter.description: If a non-null object, its properties are the function names that should be proxied even if not explicitly marked as such. If null, no functions should be proxied.

return-type.description: Returns an instance of ScriptProcessor.

property.name: DEFAULT_TIMEOUT
property.description: The default value to use when creating new Jaxer.XHR.SendOptions() objects, in milliseconds. It's only used for async requests. It defaults to 30 seconds (30000) on the server, and 0 on the client. 0 means no timeout. NOTE: To set the the default timeout to use when creating new XHR()s (i.e. XMLHttpRequests), set Jaxer.XHR.defaults.timeout instead.

class.description:
This is the namespace that contains Jaxer serialization methods. The Jaxer serializer uses the familiar and popular JSON format. However, additional functionality has been provided to allow for serialization of more complex data structures. Specifically, this module supports cyclical data structures, multiple references, and custom typeserializers. Each of these is described below. Cyclical data structures occur when an object (or array) contains a descendent structure that also references that same object. For example, a DOM node has references to its children and these children also have references to the DOM node (their parentNode). In a traditional JSON environment, if you were to try to serialize this structure, you would end up in an infinite loop or an exception would occur as the serializer traversed the parent node, its child nodes, and then back up to the parent node through the child's parentNode property. Indeed, the serializer couldn't get past the first child in this scenario. The Jaxer serializer bypasses this via the use of marker properties and specially formatted strings referred to as "references". Multiple references are similar to cyclical data structures in that an object is referenced two or more times. However, this does not necessarily create a cycle. For example, say you have the following code: 
var car = { color: "blue", price: 10000 }; var cars = [ car, car ] ;
As you can see, the same car object has been referenced twice in the array. In a traditional JSON serializer, each instance of car would be serialized separately. Unfortunately, that alters the data structure that will be accessed after deserialization in a subtle way. You will end up with two independent car objects which means that changing the price of one will not change the price of the other as would have happened before the serialization/deserialization cycle. In order to restore the same references, Jaxer serializes the car only once and then leaves placeholders to point to that single instance. During deserialization, the placeholders are replaced with actual references to the deserialized object, thus restoring the original data structure as it appeared before serialization. Some data types cannot be expressed in JSON. For example, the Date type is not listed as a valid type in JSON. So, in order to support this type and potentially many others, the serializer allows the developer to register custom serializers and associated deserializers for a given type. When the serializer sees these types, the custom handlers are used to convert the item to a string. It is then the responsibility of the custom deserializer to restore the string to the original type. For example, Jaxer supports XMLDocuments. The custom serializer creates an XML string which is specially tagged so the deserializer can restore the XML string back to an XMLDocument. Next, we briefly discuss how Jaxer recognizes cycles, multi-references, and how it represents references and custom serialized objects. The Jaxer serializer makes an initial pass over the data being serialized. Each object, array, and custom serialization object is tagged with a unique index. (Note that some objects do not allow properties to be added to them. In this situation, the Jaxer serializer maintains an array of these items. This array is searched when new items are encountered and serves the same purpose as the id property). Before adding the index, we first check if we have already indexed the item. If the tag already exists, then we've either exposed a cycle or a multi-reference. At this point, the serializer knows to switch to another JSON format that minimizes the amount of data to be serialized. References and custom serialization objects each make use of specially formatted strings. To make this a bit clearer, we create an array of two references to the same date object. 
var d = new Date(); var items = [ d, d ] ; var json = Jaxer.Serialization.toJSONString(items);
The resulting JSON string will look like the following: 
 [ [ "~1~","~1~" ] , "~Date:2007-08-17T11:57:30~" ]
This format always has a top-level array whose first element is the root item that was originally being serialized. In this case, our top-most element was an array. As an aside, the only top-level elements that can generate this format are arrays, objects, and custom serialization objects. The first special format used for references and is defined with "~ # ~" where # is a number. The number is the index into the top-level array. The element at that index is the item that needs to be referenced where the reference string lives. In this example, once deserialization has completed, both instances of "~1~" will have been replaced with references to the deserialized date object. The next custom format, the date, shows how custom serializers emit text. The first item after the ~ but before the : is the name of the type. This is the fully-qualified type as you would have to type it in JavaScript to get to that type's constructor. The string after the : is in a format as generated by the type's custom serializer. The resulting string generated by the custom serializer is in turn serialized as a string, so the deserializer does not need to handle special characters or escape sequences. It is the responsibility of the custom deserializer to consume that text and to return effectively a clone of the original object. This module also allows a developer to register alternate top-level serialization and deserialization methods. The default method for serialization is 'nativeJSON' which attempts to use the built-in JSON support in the user agent, when available. In cases where 'nativeJSON' is not supported, the 'JSON' mode will be used. The developer can also use 'JSON' along with more options to customize serialization for special values like 'undefined', and 'INFINITY', for example. Finally, there is a 'Jaxer' mode as described above. This mode is used by Jaxer's framework and callback mechanisms and is available to developers that may need this advanced functionality. These serialization methods are specificed in a separate optional parameter to the "toJSONString" and 'fromJSONString" functions. Note that if the developer uses a non-default serialization method, then the developer is also responsible for using this same method for deserialization. Currenty, this implementation cannot detect which method was used for the original serialization step

method.name: addDeserializer
method.description: Add a top-level JSON serializer

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The unique name of the deserializer. This name can be specified in the options object provided to the fromJSONString function. That will select this deserializer as the top-level function to deserialize the specified object. Note that case is not significant

parameter.name: deserializer
parameter.description: The function used to deserialized the JSON string created by the associated serializer.

parameter.name: beforeDeserialization
parameter.description: An optional function that will be called before the top-level deserialization process begins. This function should take a single parameter which will be the options object provided to the fromJSONString function. Note that the options object will be an inherited clone of the object sent to fromJSONString. This allows this function to initialize any data structures needed by the deserializer without altering the original options object passed into fromJSONString

parameter.name: afterDeserialization
parameter.description: An optional function that will be called after the top-level deserialization process ends. This function should take a single parameter which will be the options object provided to the fromJSONString function. Note that the options object will be an inherited clone of the object sent to the fromJSONString.

method.name: addSerializer
method.description: Add a top-level JSON serializer

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The unique name of the serializer. This name can be specified in the options object provided to the toJSONString function. That will select this serializer as the top-level function to serialize the specified object. Note that case is not significant

parameter.name: serializer
parameter.description: The function used to serialize data. This function should take two arguments: the actual data to serialize and an options object

parameter.name: beforeSerialization
parameter.description: An optional function that will be called before the top-level serialization process begins. This function should take a single parameter which will be the options object provided to the toJSONString function. Note that the options object will be an inherited clone of the object sent to the toJSONString. This allows this function to initialize any data structures needed by the serializer without altering the original options object passed into toJSONString

parameter.name: afterSerialization
parameter.description: An optional function that will be called after the top-level serialization process ends. This function should take a single parameter which will be the options object provided to the toJSONString function. Note that the options object will be an inherited clone of the object sent to the toJSONString.

method.name: addTypeHandler
method.description: Add handlers for custom serialization/deserialization

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The fully-qualified name of the type. This should reflect the full, potentially dotted, notation you would need to use to access this type's constructor from the global context.

parameter.name: serializer
parameter.description: A function that takes an instance of the type it serializes and that returns a string representation of the type suitable as input into the deserializer

parameter.name: deserializer
parameter.description: A function that takes a string produced by the custom serializer and that returns a new instance of the custom supported type.

parameter.name: canSerialize
parameter.description: An optional function that takes an object instance and returns a boolean. This function should return true if it the current handler is able to serialize the object passed to it.

parameter.name: canDeserialize
parameter.description: An optional function that takes an object instance and returns a boolean. This function should return true if it the current handler is able to deserialize the string passed to it.

method.name: fromJSONString
method.description: Reconstructs a Javascript data structure from a JSON string. Note that the serialization mode ('Jaxer', 'JSON', or 'nativeJSON') can be specified in the "options" parameter with the 'as' property. This will default to 'nativeJSON' when either no options are passed in or if the 'as' property is not defined. See Jaxer.Serialization.toJSONString for more details.

parameter.name: json
parameter.description: A string in the JSON format

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: The options objecct which can be used to control deserialization

return-type.description: The resulting object graph after converting the JSON string to the equivalent Javascript data structure

method.name: removeSerializer
method.description: Remove support for the custom JSON serializer

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the serializer to remove. Note that case is not significant

return-type.description: Returns true if the serializer was successfully removed. Note that this function will return false if you attempt to remove a handler that is not already registered or if it is a built-in serializer like "jaxer".

method.name: removeTypeHandler
method.description: Remove support for custom serialization/deserialization for the specified type

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The fully qualified name of the type to remove

return-type.description: Returns true if the handler was successfully removed. Note that this function will return false if you attempt to remove a handler that is not already registered.

method.name: toJSONString
method.description: Convert the specified object into a JSON representation. Note that we have modified JSON to support object references (cycles) and to convert Dates into a special format that will be recognized by our code during deserialization. This function includes an optional second parameter which can be used to control how the data is serialized. If the options parameter defines an 'as' property, that will be used to select the serialization format. Currently, the values 'Jaxer', 'JSON', and 'nativeJSON' are supported. 'Jaxer' includes support for cycles, multi-refs, and custom type serializers. 'JSON' and 'nativeJSON' follow the serialization format and semantics as defined by Douglas Crockford on the json.org website. When specifying the 'Jaxer' serializer, additional options are available. The "useCustomSerializers" has a boolean value which defaults to true. When this property is true, any type serializers that have been registered via addTypeHandler will be used in the serialization process. When this value is false, items needing custom serialization will be ignored as they would be in the "JSON" format. The "undefinedSerializationAction" property determines how the 'undefined' value is handled. The action defaults to 'serialize', but 'throw' is also supported which will throw an exception when trying to serialize 'undefined'. When specifying the 'JSON' serializer, additional options are available. The 'maxDepth' property, which defaults to 10, is used to prevent deep recursion. If the recursion level is encountered, the 'maxDepthAction' property determines the serializer's action. 'truncate' will emit a "__truncated__" string in place of the object that would cause the recursion level to be exceeded. 'throw' will throw an exception. The 'dateSerializationAction' property is used to determine how dates are processed. A value of 'serialize' will convert the date to a specially formatted string as described in the json.org example code. A value of 'throw' will throw an exception when a date is encountered. Finally, a value of "return object" will return an empty object in place of the Date itself. The 'undefinedSerializationAction' property is used to determine how 'undefined' is processed. A value of 'serialize' will convert the value to 'undefined'. 'throw' will throw an exception and 'nullify' will return 'null'. The 'specialNumberSerializationAction' property is used to determine how Infinity, -Infinity, and NaN are processed. A value of 'serialize' will convert the value to their text representation which is the same as the identifier used to represent them. 'throw' will throw an exception and 'nullify' will return null. When specifying the 'nativeJSON' serializer, the built-in native support for JSON serialization will be used, when available. This serialization does not support any custom options. In the case where 'nativeJSON' is specified but is not available, this mode will fallback to the 'JSON' mode with options specified in that mode to match the behavior of the native JSON implementation as specificed in the ECMAScript 3.1 specification. Note that other serializers can be registered with Jaxer. Most likely those serializers will define their own set of options. You will need to refer to the implementors documentation to determine those properties, their values, and their associated semantics.

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The source object to convert to a JSON string

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: An optional object used to specify configuration info to the selected serializer

return-type.description: The resulting JSON string which can be reversed back into the source object via Serialization.fromJSONString

class.description: A namespace object holding functions and members used to manage a user session across multiple requests.

method.name: keyFromRequest
method.description:
Get session key from the client via cookie, or create one as needed

(Advanced)

parameter.name: appKey
parameter.description: The key that uniquely identifies the current application

return-type.description: A session key that can be used to track the current session (new or existing)

method.name: keyToResponse
method.description:
Set session key on the response to the client via a cookie

(Advanced)

parameter.name: appKey
parameter.description: The key that uniquely identifies the current application

parameter.name: key
parameter.description: The session key to use

class.description: Network socket utility object for simple character-based (non-binary) socket access.

constructor.description: The constructor of a network socket object used for character-based (non-binary) operations

return-type.description: Returns an instance of Socket.

method.name: available
method.description: How many bytes (not characters) are currently available on the stream?

return-type.description: the number of bytes available

method.name: close
method.description: Close the socket

method.name: flush
method.description: Flush the socket's output stream

method.name: open
method.description: Open the socket for communication

parameter.name: host
parameter.description: The host to connect to

parameter.name: port
parameter.description: The port on which to connect

method.name: readLine
method.description: Read a single line from the socket

return-type.description: The text read in

method.name: readString
method.description: Read characters from the socket into a string

parameter.name: count
parameter.description: How many characters to read

return-type.description: The text read in

method.name: writeString
method.description: Write a string to the socket

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The text to write

class.description: Namespace object holding functions and members used to access operating system resources and processes.

property.name: desktopFolder
property.description: The path on disk of the current user's desktop folder

property.name: executableFolder
property.description: The path on disk of the current executable's folder

property.name: executableUrl
property.description: The file://... URL of the current executable's folder

property.name: homeFolder
property.description: The path on disk of the current user's home folder

property.name: OS
property.description: A string identifying the current operating system

property.name: separator
property.description: The filesystem separator character (either \ or /)

property.name: tempFolder
property.description: The path on disk of the system's temp folder

method.name: launch
method.description: Ask the operating system to attempt to open the file. This simulates "double clicking" the file on your platform. This routine only works on platforms which support this functionality. This is non-blocking and script execution will continue.

parameter.name: path
parameter.description: A String containing the path to the file or a Jaxer.File object referencing the filesystem object

class.description: A namespace object used to access threading-related functionality, such as async processing

property.name: currentThread
property.description: The currently executing thread.

property.name: DEFAULT_MAX_MILLIS
property.description: The default number of milliseconds to wait before timing out waitFor. Set to 3000 (3 seconds) by default).

method.name: waitFor
method.description: Allows asynchronous processing (e.g. async XHR requests, async Sandbox loading, etc.) to happen and waits for them to complete -- completion is indicated by a test function returning true. You can specify a maximum time you want to wait before giving up and continuing.

parameter.name: testFunction
parameter.description: The function to evaluate periodically to see whether we should continue to wait. When testFunction returns true, the waitFor function exits.

parameter.name: maxMillis
parameter.description: The number of milliseconds to wait for testFunction to return true before timing out and exiting. If this is zero or negative, waits indefinitely (though other timeouts may intervene)

return-type.description: true if testFunction returned true, false if the timeout was reached before then

class.description: A namespace to hold a miscellany of generic utility functions and other objects. In particular, it also holds sub-namespaces for more specific operations.

method.name: getGlobalContext
method.description:
Find the global context ('window', in the browser) to which the given object is ultimately parented. If no object is given, returns the developer page's window object, and if that does not exist for some reason, returns the framework's global context.

(Advanced)

parameter.name: obj
parameter.description: The object whose global context is to be found

return-type.description: The global context ('window', in the browser)

method.name: clone
method.description: Clones an object (actually any argument) and returns the clone. If obj is of type "object", then the clone is created from the same constructor (but without any arguments). For a deep clone, every (enumerable) property is itself cloned; otherwise, every (enumerable) property is simply copied (by value or reference).

parameter.name: obj
parameter.description: The object to clone. If it's not of type object, its value is simply copied and returned. It is not altered.

parameter.name: deep
parameter.description: Whether to make a deep clone or a shallow one (just copy properties); by default, false.

parameter.name: maxDepth
parameter.description: An optional maximum cloning depth. By default it's 10. This prevents infinite loops.

return-type.description: The new, cloned object.

method.name: concatArrays
method.description: Returns an array whose elements consist of the elements of all the arrays or array-like objects passed in as arguments. If any of the arguments is null or undefined (i.e. is equivalent to false) it is skipped.

parameter.description: Any number of arrays or array-like objects (e.g. a function's arguments meta-array). Note that, unlike Array.concat, the arguments here need to be arrays or array-like objects that have a length property and an indexer (i.e. obj [ i ] is defined)

return-type.description: The concatenated array

method.name: extend
method.description: Extends an object by (shallow) cloning it and then copying all (enumerable) properties from the extensions object to the new cloned object.

parameter.name: obj
parameter.description: The object to use as a base and extend. It is not altered.

parameter.name: extensions
parameter.description: The object to use as extensions -- usually this is a simple hashmap of properties and their values.

return-type.description: The extended clone.

method.name: filterInPlace
method.description: Remove items from an array that do not pass a given criteria. Each item in the specified array will be passed to the filtering function. If that function returns true, then the item will remain in the specified array. If the function returns false, the item is removed from the specified array. Note that the specified array is altered in place. If you prefer to create a new array, leaving the original intact, then use the native Array's filter method instead.

parameter.name: array
parameter.description: The source array to be filtered

parameter.name: func
parameter.description: The filtering function to apply to each array item. This filter has two parameters. The first parameter is the current item in the array that is potentially being filtered. The second parameter is the index of the item potentially being filtered. The index can be used in cases where the filtering decision needs to be determined based on proximity to other items in the array

return-type.description: Returns the filtered array containing only items that were approved by the filtering function. Note that this instance will be the same as the instance passed into the function. This is provided as a convenience and to keep this function signature the same as Util.filter's signature.

method.name: findInGlobalContext
method.description: Finds the named object within the global context ('window', in the browser) to which the second argument is ultimately parented. If no second argument is given, finds the named object in the developer page's window object, and if that does not exist for some reason, finds it in the Jaxer framework's global context.

parameter.name: objectName
parameter.description: The name of the object to find. If this name contains periods (".") then it's split into subnames and each is used to search in the former. So "a.b.c" means get the value of the property "a" in the global context, and in it get the value of the property "b", and in it get the value of the property "c". If any of these is not defined it returns undefined.

parameter.name: objForGlobalContext
parameter.description: The object whose global context is the one to use for finding the named object, which defaults to the developer page's window object (or else the Jaxer framework's global)

return-type.description: The found object, or undefined if it cannot be found

method.name: getPropertyNames
method.description: Get all property names or filtered subset of names from an object.

parameter.name: object
parameter.description: The source object

parameter.name: filter
parameter.description: An optional filter function to apply to the property's name and value. filter(name, value) should return something that's equivalent to true if the property is to be included.

parameter.name: asHash
parameter.description: If true, returns the result as a hash (with all values set to true)

return-type.description: A list or hash of the property names depending on the value provided to the asHash parameter

method.name: hasProperties
method.description: Determine if the specified object contains all properties in a list of property names.

parameter.name: object
parameter.description: The source object

parameter.name: properties
parameter.description: The list of property names to test on the specified object

return-type.description: Returns true if all properties in the list exist on the specified object

method.name: isArray
method.description: Tests whether the given object is an Array object (even if it's from a different global context). This returns false on Array-like objects that are not in fact arrays, such as the arguments object inside a function.

parameter.name: obj
parameter.description: The object to test

return-type.description: True if it's an Array (or at least seems to be an Array), false otherwise

method.name: isDate
method.description: Tests whether the given object is a Date object (even if it's from a different global context)

parameter.name: obj
parameter.description: The object to test

return-type.description: True if it's a Date (or at least seems to be a Date), false otherwise

method.name: isEmptyObject
method.description: Tests whether the given object is devoid of any (enumerable) properties.

parameter.name: obj
parameter.description: The object to test

return-type.description: false if there is (at least) one enumerable property, true otherwise

method.name: isNativeFunction
method.description: Tests whether the given function is native (i.e. for which there is actually no source code)

parameter.name: func
parameter.description: The function to test

return-type.description: True if it's a native function, false otherwise

method.name: isNativeFunctionSource
method.description: Tests whether the given string is the source of a native function (i.e. for which there is actually no source code)

parameter.name: source
parameter.description: The source string to test

return-type.description: True if it's a native function's source, false otherwise

method.name: mapInPlace
method.description: Replace each item of an array by applying a function and then replacing the original item with the results of that function.

parameter.name: array
parameter.description: The source array

parameter.name: func
parameter.description: The function to apply to each of the items in the source array. The function has two parameters. The first parameter is the current item in the array that is being transformed. The second parameter is the index of the item being transformed.

return-type.description: Returns the mapped array. Note that this instance will be the same as the instance passed into the function. This is provided as a convenience and to keep this function's signature the same as the signature of the native Array's map mathod.

method.name: sleep
method.description: Does nothing for the given number of milliseconds

parameter.name: milliseconds
parameter.description: The number of milliseconds to pause.

class.description: Namespace used to hold functions and other objects for using CRC32

method.name: getCRC
method.description: Create a CRC32 from an array of bytes. The user may specify the starting offset within the array and the total number of bytes past the offset to include in the resulting CRC32.

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: An array of byte values

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: The optional offset within the array where the calculated CRC32 should start

parameter.name: count
parameter.description: The optional number of bytes starting from the offset to include in the resulting CRC32.

return-type.description: The resulting CRC32

method.name: getStringCRC
method.description: Create a CRC32 from the characters of a string

parameter.name: text
parameter.description: The source string to convert

return-type.description: The resulting CRC32 of the source string

class.description: Namespace used for handling information related to SSL certificates
Information about an SSL Certificate

constructor.description: Holds information about an SSL certificate and the SSL connection that returned it. It repackages the information in the Mozilla objects used to construct it.

parameter.name: socketInfo
parameter.description: A network communication context that can be used to obtain more information about the connection relevant to this certificate. This is an instance of Mozilla's nsIInterfaceRequestor (http://www.xulplanet.com/references/xpcomref/ifaces/nsIInterfaceRequestor.html)

parameter.name: sslStatus
parameter.description: A Mozilla object that contains information about the certificate. This is an instance of Mozilla's nsISSLStatus (http://www.xulplanet.com/references/xpcomref/ifaces/nsISSLStatus.html)

parameter.name: targetSite
parameter.description: The site name that was used to open the connection from which the certificate was returned

return-type.description: Returns an instance of CertInfo.

property.name: cert
property.description: The Mozilla object representing an X.509 certificate. See nsIX509Cert (http://www.xulplanet.com/references/xpcomref/ifaces/nsIX509Cert.html)

property.name: emailAddress
property.description: The primary email address of the certificate, if present.

property.name: isDomainMismatch
property.description: Is there a domain mismatch between the domain on this certificate and the domain that served it?

property.name: isNotValidAtThisTime
property.description: Is this certificate not trusted at this time -- because its validity period has not yet started or has already ended?

property.name: isSelfSigned
property.description: Is this a self-signed certificate?

property.name: issuerName
property.description: The subject identifying the issuer certificate.

property.name: issuerOrganization
property.description: The issuer subject's organization.

property.name: isUntrusted
property.description: Is this certificate untrusted -- either because it has a missing or untrusted issuer or because it is self-signed?

property.name: organization
property.description: The subject's organization.

property.name: subjectName
property.description: The subject owning the certificate.

property.name: targetSite
property.description: The site name that was used to open the connection from which the certificate was returned.

property.name: validity
property.description: This certificate's validity period: the notBefore date, followed by '/', followed by the notAfter date.

class.description: Namespace object holding functions and members for working with client (browser) cookies on the server side.

method.name: get
method.description: Get a cookie key value

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the cookie to retrieve

return-type.description: Returns the value of the specified cookie or null if the value does not exist.

method.name: getAll
method.description: Get an object containing all cookie keys and values from the current request. Each cookie name will become a property on the object and each cookie value will become that property's value.

return-type.description: The resulting object of all cookie key/value pairs

method.name: parseSetCookieHeaders
method.description: Parses a given array of an HTTP response's "Set-Cookie" header strings to extract the cookie fields

parameter.name: setCookieStrings
parameter.description: An array of the (string) values of the HTTP response's Set-Cookie headers

return-type.description: An array of objects, one per Set-Cookie header, with properties corresponding to the name, value, expires, path, and domain values in the header

method.name: set
method.description: Set a cookie name/value pair

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the cookie to set

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: The value of the cookie

class.description: Namespace used to hold functions and other objects that extend JavaScript's DOM capabilities.

method.name: createScript
method.description: Create a new script element with the specified content and attributes

parameter.name: doc
parameter.description: The DocumentElement to use when creating elements for the active document.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.description: The text content for the script element. This value will be set via innerHTML once the new script element has been created

parameter.name: attributes
parameter.description: A list of attributes and attribute values to apply to the new ScriptElement. Each property name will become the attribute name and each property value will become that attributes value. Note that no escaping is done on the attributes values, so it is expected those values are valid attribute values. If this is omitted, a default type attribute will be used if set in Jaxer.Config.DEFAULT_EMITTED_SCRIPT_TYPE

return-type.description: The new script element with content and attributes applied.

method.name: hashToAttributesString
method.description: Convert an object's properties and property values into a string of attributes suitable for use in creating a string representation of an HTMLElement. Each property is used as the attribute name and each property value becomes the attribute value. Attribute values are surrounding in double-quotes and all property values containing double-quotes will have those characters escaped with backslashes.

parameter.name: hash
parameter.description: The source object

return-type.description: The resulting string of attribute name/value pairs

method.name: insertScriptAfter
method.description: Creates a new script element and adds it as the next sibling of the specified element in the DOM.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.description: The text content for the script element. This value will be set via innerHTML once the new script element has been created

parameter.name: elt
parameter.description: The element in the DOM after which the new script element will be inserted

parameter.name: attributes
parameter.description: A list of attributes and attribute values to apply to the new ScriptElement. Each property name will become the attribute name and each property value will become that attributes value. Note that no escaping is done on the attributes values, so it is expected those values are valid attribute values

return-type.description: The new script element with content and attributes applied.

method.name: insertScriptAtBeginning
method.description: Creates a new script element and adds it as the first child of a specified element in the DOM.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.description: The text content for the script element. This value will be set via innerHTML once the new script element has been created

parameter.name: elt
parameter.description: The element in the DOM where the new script element will be added as the element's first child.

parameter.name: attributes
parameter.description: A list of attributes and attribute values to apply to the new ScriptElement. Each property name will become the attribute name and each property value will become that attributes value. Note that no escaping is done on the attributes values, so it is expected those values are valid attribute values

return-type.description: The new script element with content and attributes applied.

method.name: insertScriptAtEnd
method.description: Creates a new script element and adds it as the last child of a specified element in the DOM.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.description: The text content for the script element. This value will be set via innerHTML once the new script element has been created

parameter.name: elt
parameter.description: The element in the DOM where the new script element will be added as the element's last child.

parameter.name: attributes
parameter.description: A list of attributes and attribute values to apply to the new ScriptElement. Each property name will become the attribute name and each property value will become that attributes value. Note that no escaping is done on the attributes values, so it is expected those values are valid attribute values

return-type.description: The new script element with content and attributes applied.

method.name: insertScriptBefore
method.description: Creates a new script element and adds it before a specified element in the DOM.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.description: The text content for the script element. This value will be set via innerHTML once the new script element has been created

parameter.name: elt
parameter.description: The element in the DOM before which the new script element will be inserted

parameter.name: attributes
parameter.description: A list of attributes and attribute values to apply to the new ScriptElement. Each property name will become the attribute name and each property value will become that attributes value. Note that no escaping is done on the attributes values, so it is expected those values are valid attribute values

return-type.description: The new script element with content and attributes applied.

method.name: replaceWithScript
method.description: Replace a specified element in the DOM with a new script element.

parameter.name: contents
parameter.description: The text content for the script element. This value will be set via innerHTML once the new script element has been created

parameter.name: elt
parameter.description: The element to replace with the a script element

parameter.name: attributes
parameter.description: A list of attributes and attribute values to apply to the new ScriptElement. Each property name will become the attribute name and each property value will become that attributes value. Note that no escaping is done on the attributes values, so it is expected those values are valid attribute values

return-type.description: The new script element with content and attributes applied.

method.name: toHTML
method.description: Returns the serialized HTML of the given node and its contents, much like the outerHTML property in IE. You can also pass the entire document as the node to get the entire HTML of the document (page).

parameter.name: node
parameter.description: The HTML element or document (or DOM node) to be serialized

return-type.description: The HTML text

class.description: Namespace used to hold functions and other objects that extend JavaScript's datetime handling.

method.name: toPaddedString
method.description: Converts a date to a string and pads the month and date values to align all date values in columns. Not yet internationalized.

parameter.name: date
parameter.description: The source date

return-type.description: The source data converted to a string with month and data values padded with spaces to align all values

class.description: Namespace used to hold functions and other objects that extend JavaScript's math capabilities

method.name: forceInteger
method.description: Forces num into a finite integer. If it's a string, it first attempts to parse it to an integer. If it's a number, it takes its integer part by applying Math.floor() to it. If it's anything else, o NaN (not a number), it uses the defaultNum or 0.

parameter.name: num
parameter.description: The object to turn into an integer

parameter.name: defaultNum
parameter.description: The integer to use as a default (which will itself be forced to be 0 if not an integer)

method.name: isInteger
method.description: Determine whether the specified value is an integer value

parameter.name: num
parameter.description: The number to test

return-type.description: Returns true if the number is an integer value

class.description: Namespace used to hold functions that create and manipulate a hash whose values are primitives or Arrays of primitives

method.name: add
method.description: Adds the name-value pair to the MultiHash: if the name does not exist, it is added with the given value; if the name exists, the previous value is turned into an Array, if needed, and then the given value is appended to it

parameter.name: multiHash
parameter.description: The multihash to which the name-value should be added

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name to use as a key

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: The value to associate with the key -- it must not be an array

method.name: diff
method.description: Analyzes the first MultiHash relative to the second

parameter.name: after
parameter.description: The MultiHash whose changes we are interested in

parameter.name: before
parameter.description: The MultiHash relative to which the changes have occurred

return-type.description: The results of the analysis, an object with three properties: 'added' is a hash of all the name-value pairs added; 'changed' is a hash of all the name-value pairs that have changed (the value is the one in after); and 'deleted' is a hash of all the name-value pairs that have been deleted (the value is the one in before, of course)

method.name: remove
method.description: Removes the name-value pair from the MultiHash: if the name does not exist, or it does not have the value, nothing happens; if the name exists and has the value, that value is removed, and if no more values remain for that name, the name is removed

parameter.name: multiHash
parameter.description: The multihash from which the name-value should be removed

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the key

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: The value to remove from the key -- it must not be an array

class.description: The namespace that holds functions timing javascript

property.name: clocks
property.description: A hashmap keyed by timer label, each element contains the timestamp last set.

property.name: laps
property.description: A hashmap keyed by lap label, each element contains the timestamp last set.

property.name: timings
property.description: A hashmap keyed by timer label, each element contains an Array of timing measurements.

method.name: flush
method.description: This method is invoked to analyze/save/display the currently stored measurement timers. If no function parameter is provided then contents of the measurement timers are written to the logfile. If a function is provided then it is invoked with the timings hashmap (Jaxer.Util.Stopwatch.timings) as the only parameter.

parameter.name: fn
parameter.description: The provided function is executed before all current timers are cleared. The function is provided the timings hashmap (Jaxer.Util.Stopwatch.timings) as the only parameter.

method.name: lap
method.description: A lap timer which will store the delta between each invocation for later analysis

parameter.name: label
parameter.description: A label to uniquely identify this measurement timer

method.name: lapCount
method.description: This method returns the value of the lapcounter for the provided label.

parameter.name: label
parameter.description: A label to uniquely identify this measurement timer

method.name: reset
method.description: Reset all the currently managed timers

method.name: start
method.description: Start a timer for the provided label

parameter.name: label
parameter.description: A label to uniquely identify this measurement timer

method.name: stop
method.description: Stops the current timer and stores the result for later analysis

parameter.name: label
parameter.description: A label to uniquely identify this measurement timer

class.description: Namespace that holds functions and other objects that extend JavaScript's string capabilities.

method.name: endsWith
method.description: Check to see if a string ends with a string

parameter.name: inString
parameter.description: The string to look in

parameter.name: lookFor
parameter.description: The string to look for

parameter.name: ignoreCase
parameter.description: Set to true for case insensitive searches

return-type.description: true if the string ends with the provided string

method.name: escapeForJS
method.description: Escapes an input string for use with javascript

parameter.name: raw
parameter.description: The source string

return-type.description: The escaped string suitable for use in an eval statement

method.name: escapeForSQL
method.description: Escapes an input string for use with SQL

parameter.name: raw
parameter.description: The source string

return-type.description: The escaped string suitable for use in a SQL query

method.name: grep
method.description: Searches the given lines for the given pattern, and returns the lines that matched.

parameter.name: stringOrArray
parameter.description: The string to search through, which will be split up into its lines, or an array of lines (i.e. a string that has already been split)

parameter.name: pattern
parameter.description: The string pattern to look for, which will be turned into a RegExp, or the RegExp to match

return-type.description: An array of the lines that matched the pattern

method.name: singleQuote
method.description: Surround the provided string in single quotation marks

parameter.name: text
parameter.description: The original string

return-type.description: The original string encased in single quotes

method.name: startsWith
method.description: Check to see if a string starts with another string

parameter.name: inString
parameter.description: The string to look in

parameter.name: lookFor
parameter.description: The string to look for

parameter.name: ignoreCase
parameter.description: Set to true for case insensitive searches

return-type.description: true if the string starts with the provided string

method.name: trim
method.description: Left or right trim the provided string. Optionally, you can specify a list of characters (as a single string) to trim from the source string. By default, whitespace is removed. Also, you can control which side of the string (start or end) is trimmed with the default being both sides.

parameter.name: str
parameter.description: The source string

parameter.name: charsToTrim
parameter.description: This optional parameter can be used to specify a list of characters to remove from the sides of the source string. Any combination of these characters will be removed. If this parameter is not specified, then all whitespace characters will be removed.

parameter.name: leftOrRight
parameter.description: This optional parameter can be used to control which side of the string is trimmed. A value of "L" will trim the start of the string and all other string values will trim the end of the string. If this parameter is not specified, then both sides of the string will be trimmed

return-type.description: The resulting trimmed string

method.name: upperCaseToCamelCase
method.description: Convert a string to a CamelCase representation by removing interword spaces and capitalizing the first letter of each word following an underscore

parameter.name: orig
parameter.description: The orignal string containing underscores between words

return-type.description: The resulting string with underscores removed and the first letter of a word capitalized

class.description: Namespace that holds functions and other objects for working with URLs.

method.name: combine
method.description: Combines any number of URL fragments into a single URL, using / as the separator. Before joining two fragments with the separator, it strips any existing separators on the fragment ends to be joined

parameter.description: Takes any number of string URL fragments

return-type.description: The fragments joined into a URL

method.name: ensureFileProtocol
method.description: If the given URL is already a file-type URL, it's returned untouched. Otherwise we turn it into a file-type URL by prefixing it with "file://"

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL to apply this to

return-type.description: URL expressed as a file type URL

method.name: formUrlDecode
method.description: Decode a URL by replacing +'s with spaces and all hex values (%xx) with their character value

parameter.name: str
parameter.description: The source URL to decode

return-type.description: The resulting URL after all hex values have been converted

method.name: formUrlEncode
method.description: Encode a URL by replacing all special characters with hex values (%xx)

parameter.name: str
parameter.description: The string to encode

return-type.description: The resulting URL after special characters and spaces have been encoded

method.name: hashToQuery
method.description: Converts an object's properties and property values to a string suitable as a query string. Each property name becomes a key in the query string and each property value becomes the key value. A key and its value are separated by the '=' character. Each key/value pair is separated by '&'. Note that each value is encoded so invalid URL characters are encoded properly.

parameter.name: hash
parameter.description: The object to convert to a query string

return-type.description: The resulting query string

method.name: isFile
method.description: Tests whether the given URL is a reasonable file URL rather than something that's available over the network.The test is pretty simplistic: the URL must start with file://, resource://, or chrome://, or it must contain a backslash (i.e. a Windows filesystem separator)

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL to test

return-type.description: True if a reasonable file URL, false otherwise

method.name: parseUrl
method.description: Parse a string containing a URL into a Jaxer.Util.Url.ParsedUrl object to allow manipulation of the individual URL component parts

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL to parse

return-type.description: The parts of a URL broken down into useful pieces

method.name: parseUrlComponents
method.description: Create a Util.Url.ParsedUrl object from the component pieces provided as parameters to the functions calls.

parameter.name: hostAndPort
parameter.description: The host (and port, if any) containing the given path

parameter.name: absolutePath
parameter.description: The absolute path to a resource on the host

parameter.name: protocol
parameter.description: The protocol ('http' or 'https'); the default is 'http'

return-type.description: The parts of a URL broken down into useful pieces

method.name: queryToHash
method.description: Divides the key/value pairs in a query string and builds an object for these values. The key will become the property name of the object and the value will become the value of that property

parameter.name: query
parameter.description: A query string

class.description: An object describing the parsed pieces of a URL.

constructor.description: An object describing the parsed pieces of a URL. This object contains sub properties to allow access to the individual pieces of the URL

return-type.description: Returns an instance of ParsedUrl.

property.name: authority
property.description: The complete authority (e.g. 'user1@www.aptana.com:8081'), or '' if not specified. Note that the userInfo ('user1') and/or the port ('8081') may not be present.

property.name: base
property.description: The protocol, userInfo, host, and port (e.g. 'http://user1@www.aptana.com:8081'), which might not have a protocol or a port if they were not specified

property.name: domain
property.description: The highest-level non-TLD domain (e.g. 'aptana.com' in 'www.playground.aptana.com'), or the IP address if the host was an IP address

property.name: fragment
property.description: The fragment string (e.g. 'myBookmark') after the # symbol (e.g. # myBookmark), or '' if not specified

property.name: host
property.description: The host (e.g. 'www.aptana.com'), or '' if not specified.

property.name: hostAndPort
property.description: The combined host and port (e.g. 'www.aptana.com:8081'), which might be just the host if no port was specified. A synonym for the authority property.

property.name: leaf
property.description: The last part of the path, namely everything after the last / and before any query or fragment (e.g. "logo.png" in 'http://www.aptana.com/images/small/logo.png?v=12'). If the path ends in a trailing /, this is the empty string. And if the path is completely absent, this is null.

property.name: path
property.description: The entire path (e.g. '/images/myImage.gif') between the hostAndPort and the query string or fragment (if any), or '' if none

property.name: pathParts
property.description: A possibly-empty array of strings that compose the path part of the URL (e.g. [ "images", "small", "logo.png" ] in 'http://www.aptana.com/images/small/logo.png?v=12'). Note that if the path ends in a /, the last element in the pathParts array (a.k.a. the leaf) will be the empty string.

property.name: port
property.description: The port as a string (e.g. '80'), or '' if not specified

property.name: protocol
property.description: The protocol (typically 'http' or 'https'), or '' if not specified. A synonym for the scheme property.

property.name: query
property.description: The query string (e.g. 'name=joe&id=12') after the (first) question mark (?), or '' if not specified

property.name: queryParts
property.description: An object containing a property for each name=value pair in the query string of the URL, e.g. 'http://www.aptana.com/staff?name=joe&id=12' leads to queryParts.name = "joe" and queryParts.id = "12"

property.name: scheme
property.description: The scheme (typically 'http' or 'https'), or '' if not specified. A synonym for the protocol property.

property.name: subdomain
property.description: The subdomain (e.g. 'www.playground' in 'www.playground.aptana.com') before the domain, or '' if none or if the host was an IP address

property.name: url
property.description: The complete (but whitespace-trimmed) original URL, before parsing

property.name: userInfo
property.description: The userInfo in the URL (e.g. 'user1' in 'user1@www.aptana.com'), or '' if not specified.

class.description: Namespace object holding functions and members used to resolve and fetch web resources. Fetching is done via XMLHttpRequests.

property.name: ACTIONS
property.description: An enumeration of constants for various standard HTTP methods or actions

method.name: getDefaultReferenceUrl
method.description:
Returns the URL to be used as a reference for resolving relative URLs if no other reference is given

(Advanced)

return-type.description: The absolute URL

method.name: del
method.description: Send a DELETE-type HTTP request to a URL and return the response.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL of the page to send the request. This will first be resolved by Web.resolve().

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The text of the response, or the XML DOM if the response was an XML document. Set the "as" property in the options argument to "text" or "xml" to force what is returned. An Exception is thrown if not successful.

method.name: get
method.description: Fetch a document from a URL by resolving it to a local file (if it starts with file://) or by a GET command.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL to fetch, which may be a file:// URL if desired. This will first be resolved by Dir.resolve() or Web.resolve().

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The text of the requested document, or the XML DOM if the response was an XML document. Set the "as" property in the options argument to "text" or "xml" to force what is returned. An Exception is thrown if not successful.

method.name: head
method.description: Send a HEAD-type HTTP request to a URL and return the response.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL of the page to send the request. This will first be resolved by Web.resolve().

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The text of the response, or the XML DOM if the response was an XML document. Set the "as" property in the options argument to "text" or "xml" to force what is returned. An Exception is thrown if not successful.

method.name: open
method.description: GET or POST data to a URL, loading the result into the window of a new Jaxer.Sandbox object.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL of the page to GET or POST to. This will first be resolved by Web.resolve().

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The data to submit, if any. If this parameter is omitted or is null, a GET is used; otherwise a POST is used. If this is a string, it should usually be a query string in a format (name1=value1&name2=value2) suitable for a Content-Type of 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'. If an object, its enumerable properties will be used to construct the query string.

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The Sandbox, which will usually have a window and document in it (if the request was successful and returned an HTML page)

method.name: options
method.description: Send an OPTIONS-type HTTP request to a URL and return the response.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL of the page to send the request. This will first be resolved by Web.resolve().

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The data to submit. If a string, it should be a query string in a format (name1=value1&name2=value2) suitable for a Content-Type of 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'. If an object, its enumerable properties will be used to construct the query string.

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The text of the response, or the XML DOM if the response was an XML document. Set the "as" property in the options argument to "text" or "xml" to force what is returned. An Exception is thrown if not successful.

method.name: post
method.description: POST data to a URL and return the response web page.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL of the page to POST to and fetch. This will first be resolved by Web.resolve().

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The data to submit. If a string, it should be a query string in a format (name1=value1&name2=value2) suitable for a Content-Type of 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'. If an object, its enumerable properties will be used to construct the query string.

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The text of the response, or the XML DOM if the response was an XML document. Set the "as" property in the options argument to "text" or "xml" to force what is returned. An Exception is thrown if not successful.

method.name: put
method.description: Send a PUT-type HTTP request to a URL and return the response.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL of the page to send the request. This will first be resolved by Web.resolve().

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The data to submit. If a string, it should be a query string in a format (name1=value1&name2=value2) suitable for a Content-Type of 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'. If an object, its enumerable properties will be used to construct the query string.

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The text of the response, or the XML DOM if the response was an XML document. Set the "as" property in the options argument to "text" or "xml" to force what is returned. An Exception is thrown if not successful.

method.name: resolve
method.description: Resolves a URL to an absolute URL (one starting with protocol://domain...) To resolve a relative URL (with or without a leading /), use a current document or callback for reference. Uses the base href of the current document, if specified. If Jaxer.Config.REWRITE_TO_FILE_URL_REGEX exists and matches the url, the url is resolved as a file-type URL: it will use the given referenceUrl if it's already a file-based one, otherwise it will use the Jaxer.request.documentRoot for an absolute url or Jaxer.request.currentFolder for a relative url. If Jaxer.Config.REWRITE_RELATIVE_URL exists (and we're not dealing in file-based URLs), its value is used to rewrite the relative url -- replacing Jaxer.Config.REWRITE_RELATIVE_URL_REGEX pattern, if it exists, else replacing http [ s ] :// followed by anything but a slash.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The URL to resolve

parameter.name: referenceUrl
parameter.description: An optional reference URL to use, overriding the built-in logic

return-type.description: The fully-resolved URL, or the original URL if the input was already an absolute URL

method.name: send
method.description: A generalized method to access a web URL via the built-in XMLHttpRequest object.

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: The url to access

parameter.name: method
parameter.description: Usually 'GET' (default) or 'POST'

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: Use for POST submissions, or for GET requests if the url does not already contain the data. This may be a string (usually of the form name1=value&name2=value), or an object whose name->value property pairs will be used to construct such a string.

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: Options for finer control of how the request is made.

return-type.description: The text of the requested document, or the XML DOM if the response was an XML document. Set the "as" property in the options argument to "text" or "xml" or "e4x" to force what is returned. An Exception is thrown if not successful.

property.name: DELETE
property.description: A constant describing the standard HTTP DELETE method (or action)

property.name: GET
property.description: A constant describing the standard HTTP GET method (or action)

property.name: HEAD
property.description: A constant describing the standard HTTP HEAD method (or action)

property.name: OPTIONS
property.description: A constant describing the standard HTTP OPTIONS method (or action)

property.name: POST
property.description: A constant describing the standard HTTP POST method (or action)

property.name: PUT
property.description: A constant describing the standard HTTP PUT method (or action)

class.description: Namespace to hold the Jaxer client-side cross-browser wrapper around XMLHttpRequest.

property.name: REASON_FAILURE
property.description:
The value of the "reason" property that indicates a communication failure has occurred. This property is set on the Error object that's thrown by XHR.send() during synchronous requests that don't use the onsuccess function but rather just return a response or throw an Error.

(Advanced)

property.name: REASON_TIMEOUT
property.description:
The value of the "reason" property that indicates a timeout has occurred. This property is set on the Error object that's thrown by XHR.send() during synchronous requests that don't use the onsuccess function but rather just return a response or throw an Error.

(Advanced)

property.name: defaults
property.description: The default SendOptions which new calls to Jaxer.XHR.send(message, options, extra) will use, unless overridden by the options argument. This is slightly different for client-side and server-side requests (e.g. server-side requests are by default synchronous).

method.name: getTransport
method.description:
Returns an XMLHttpRequest object by calling the platform-specific API for it. On the server side of Jaxer, the XPCOM version of XMLHttpRequest is used.

(Advanced)

method.name: onfailure
method.description:
The default client-side function used to handle any errors that occur during XMLHttpRequest processing by throwing an error describing them

(Advanced)

parameter.name: error
parameter.description: An error object describing the error, if one was thrown. Otherwise this is null.

parameter.name: extra
parameter.description: Any extra information passed into Jaxer.XHR.send(), e.g. to make error messages more informative.

parameter.name: xhr
parameter.description: The XMLHttpRequest object that contains the information received from the server, e.g. in xhr.status and xhr.responseText. It may be null if an error was encountered creating it.

method.name: ontimeout
method.description:
The default client-side function used to handle any timeout errors that occur during XMLHttpRequest processing by throwing an error describing them

(Advanced)

parameter.name: timeout
parameter.description: The timeout error object encountered, having a "timeout" property with its value indicating the timeout (in milliseconds) used in this request.

parameter.name: extra
parameter.description: Any extra information passed into Jaxer.XHR.send(), e.g. to make error messages more informative.

parameter.name: xhr
parameter.description: The XMLHttpRequest object that contains the information received from the server, e.g. in xhr.status and xhr.responseText. It may be null if an error was encountered creating it.

method.name: testSuccess
method.description:
The default function used to test whether the XMLHttpRequest got a successful response or not, in particular using xhr.status, location.protocol and some browser sniffing.

(Advanced)

parameter.name: xhr
parameter.description: The XMLHttpRequest object that got the response

return-type.description: true if successful, false otherwise

method.name: cancel
method.description: Cancels the pending async XMLHttpRequest if its response has not yet been received and if it has not yet timed out.

parameter.name: asyncKey
parameter.description: The key that Jaxer.XHR.send() returned when the request was created.

return-type.description: true if the request was found and canceled, false if it was not found (i.e. was not in the pending queue)

method.name: send
method.description:
The generic function used to send requests via XMLHttpRequest objects. Each request gets its own XMLHttpRequest object, and async requests hold onto that object until they're finished or timed out or canceled. On the server side of Jaxer, only synchronous requests are supported.

For async requests, this returns a key that can be used to abort the request via Jaxer.XHR.cancel().

For synchronous requests, returns the response of the server or throws an exception if an error occurred, unless an onsuccess function was specified in the options, in which case it passes the response to that function and also handles any errors through the onfailure function if specified in the options.

In any case, the response can be a text string or an XML DOM. To force one or the other, set the "as" property on the options argument, e.g. if as="text" it will definitely be a text string, if as="xml" it will definitely be an XML DOM, and if as="e4x" it will be an E4X DOM (if E4X is supported -- which is always the case server-side but may not be client-side).

parameter.name: message
parameter.description: The message to send, usually as a query string ("name1=value&name2=value2...")

parameter.name: options
parameter.description: A JavaScript object (hashmap) of name: value property pairs specifying how to handle this request.

parameter.name: extra
parameter.description: Any extra information that might be useful e.g. in the error handlers on this request. This object is simply passed on to them if/when they're called. E.g. Jaxer.Callback uses this information to pass the name of the function being called remotely, so error messages can be more informative.

return-type.description: For async requests, a key to the XHR object; for synchronous requests (with no onsuccess handler in the options), a text string or an XML DOM, or an object containing detailed information about the response (if the options specified extendedResponse=true)

class.description: A hashmap containing detaild information about the response from an XHR.send.

constructor.description: A hashmap containing detailed information about the response from an XHR.send. This is returned as the response of XHR.send when the SendOptions specify extendedResponse=true.

return-type.description: Returns an instance of ResponseData.

property.name: certInfo
property.description: Information about the SSL certificate used in this request-response. This is only available server-side. NOTE: currently this is only available when an SSL certificate error was encountered, and the onsslcerterror function was set and returned true.

property.name: cookies
property.description: An array of cooky directives indicated in the response via the "Set-Cookie" header. Each cookie is represented by an object with properties corresponding to its name, value, expires, path, and domain.

property.name: extra
property.description: The value of the "extra" parameter, if any, passed into XHR.send.

property.name: headers
property.description: A hashmap containing properties corresponding to the names of the response headers. For each property, if the header name was present multiple times in the response, the value of the property is an array of the corresponding header values; otherwise, the value of the property is the value of the header.

property.name: response
property.description: The responseText string or responseXML XMLDocument of the response, depending on the SendOptions and the returned content type

property.name: status
property.description: The HTTP status code of the response (e.g. 200)

property.name: statusText
property.description: The HTTP status text of the response (e.g. "OK")

property.name: text
property.description: The responseText of the response, or null if none

property.name: xhr
property.description: The XMLHttpRequest object used in the request-response

property.name: xml
property.description: The responseXML of the response, or null if none

class.description: Options used to define the behavior of Jaxer.XHR.send.

constructor.description: Options used to define the behavior of Jaxer.XHR.send. Create a new Jaxer.XHR.SendOptions() to get the default options, then modify its properties as needed before passing it to Jaxer.XHR.send.

return-type.description: Returns an instance of SendOptions.

property.name: pollingPeriod
property.description:
For async requests, the number of milliseconds between polling for onreadystatechange, by default 11

(Advanced)

property.name: as
property.description: Set to "text" to force interpreting the response as text regardless of mimetype. Set to "xml" to force interpreting the response as XML regardless of mimetype and returning the XML as an XML (DOM) object via XMLHttpRequest.responseXML. Set to null to not force anything - see overrideMimeType and responseType for finer control.

property.name: async
property.description: Set to true for asynchronous, false for synchronous. By default it's true client-side and false server-side. To use it server-side, see also Jaxer.Thread.waitFor.

property.name: cacheBuster
property.description: If true (default, client-side), a random name and value query pair will be appended to the URL on each call

property.name: contentType
property.description: The content type of the request being sent (by default "application/x-www-form-urlencoded")

property.name: getTransport
property.description: The function to use to create the XMLHttpRequest, by default XHR.getTransport

property.name: headers
property.description: Set to null to use default headers; set to an array of [ name, value ] arrays to use custom headers instead, or to an object containing properties to use as the headers

property.name: method
property.description: Should be "GET" (default, server-side) or "POST" (default, client-side)

property.name: onfailure
property.description: Set to a custom callback function to call if unsuccessful (by default set to Jaxer.XHR.onfailure client-side). Its arguments are the error encountered, the "extra" information from the caller, and the XHR instance.

property.name: onfinished
property.description: Set to a custom function to call when done receiving (or timed out), usually to abort()

property.name: onreadytosend
property.description: Set to a custom function to call just before sending (e.g. to set custom headers, mimetype, keep reference to xhr object, etc.)

property.name: onsslcerterror
property.description: Set to a custom callback function to call if an SSL request fails due to a certificate error. Its arguments are the certInfo (an object containing properties describing the certificate and its status), the cert, and the XHR's socketInfo, sslStatus, and targetSite. It should return true to ignore the error, or false to abort the request. This is only available server-side. If (and only if) this is set to a function that returns true, information about the failure can be retrieved from the extended response's certInfo property.

property.name: onsuccess
property.description: Set to a function to call if successful. Its arguments are the response received back from the server, and any "extra" information passed in when calling send(). For synchronous calls, you can optionally set onsuccess to null to have XHR.send() return a value directly (and throw errors on failure/timeout).

property.name: ontimeout
property.description: Set to a custom timeout function to call if timeout is used and the async request has timed out. Its arguments are the timeout error encountered, the "extra" information from the caller, and the XHR instance.

property.name: overrideMimeType
property.description: Set to null to use whatever mimetype the server sends in the response; set to a mimetype string (e.g. "text/plain") to force the response to be interpreted using the given mimetype

property.name: password
property.description: If the target URL requires authentication, specify this password, otherwise leave this as null.

property.name: responseText
property.description: Set to "text" (default) to use the responseText, to "xml" to use the responseXML, or "auto" to use the response's content-type to choose

property.name: testSuccess
property.description: Set to a custom function that receives the XMLHttpRequest (after readyState == 4) and tests whether it succeeded (by default Jaxer.XHR.testSuccess)

property.name: timeout
property.description: For async (client-side) requests, set to number of milliseconds before timing out, or 0 to wait indefinitely

property.name: url
property.description: The URL to which the XMLHttpRequest is to be sent. On the client side, defaults to Jaxer.CALLBACK_URI which is used to handle function callbacks from client-side proxies to their server-side counterparts.

property.name: username
property.description: If the target URL requires authentication, specify this username, otherwise leave this as null.

property.name: extendedResponse
property.description: If this is set to true, the response returned directly or passed to an onsuccess handler will contain detailed information about the response, in the form of a Jaxer.XHR.ResponseData object.

property.name: timeout
property.description: The default value to use when creating new Jaxer.XHR (XMLHttpRequest) requests, in milliseconds. This also applies to anything that uses XHRs, such as Jaxer.Web.get. It's only used for async requests. It defaults to 30 seconds (30000) on the server, and 0 on the client. 0 means no timeout. NOTE: To set the the default timeout to use when creating new XHR.SendOptions() objects, set Jaxer.XHR.SendOptions.timeout instead.
